div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7239] ALEXANDRIA, THURSDAY, JULY 13, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p: This Company's system of submarine telegraph cables is the most direct and quickest means of communication from Egypt to Europe, North and South America, East, South and West Africa, India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.
To secure quick transmission, telegrams should be marked Via Eastern.
For latest average time to London, see daily bulletin in this paper.
STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo, Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Said, Suakin. Head Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

R.M.S. "Oroya" will leave Port Said about July 18 | R.M.S. "Ortona" will leave Port Said about August 1
Egyptian Government Officials allowed a rebate of 15% off the above fares.

Return tickets no longer issued, but passengers paying full fare in one direction allowed abatement of 1/3 fare back if return voyage be within 4 months of arrival, or abatement of 20 o/o if return voyage be made within 8 months of arrival.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: FAST BRITISH PASSENGER STEAMERS
GREECE - TURKEY LINE.
Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.
PALESTINE - SYRIA LINE.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).
RED SEA LINE.

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency. 31-12-904

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
S.S. Seti now on the berth, will sail on or about Monday, July 17, to be followed by S.S. Menes.
S.S Tabor for Havre via Malta to sail about Saturday l5th inst.

R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents. 26-12-905

Officially appointed & Sole Agents in Cairo to the P.&O. S.N. Co.

RESIDENTS IN EGYPT proceeding to Europe for the summer are requested to apply to our offices for information respecting their Passages, where steamer plans may be consulted and Berths secured by all Lines of Steamers to all parts of the Globe; arrangements can also be made for the collection and forwarding of their baggage and clearance at port of arrival.

CIRCULAR NOTES issued payable at the current rate of exchange in all the principal cities of Europe. Cook's Interpreters in uniform are present at the principal Railway stations and Landing-places in Europe to assist passengers holding their travelling tickets.

Large and splendidly appointed steamers belonging to the Co. leave Cairo thrice weekly, between November and March, for Luxor, Assouan and Wady-Halfa in connection with trains de luxe to Khartoum. Moderate fares.
FREIGHT SERVICE, Steamers leave Cairo every Saturday and Tuesday for Assouan and Halfa.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd's Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste.

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday a.m. in time for express to Paris, London, Naples, Rome. Arrival Trieste Wednesday noon connecting with Vienna Express (Trieste-Ostende through carriage) and expresses to Italy and Germany.
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste

MANUFACTURERS OF THE LARGEST AND MOST EFFICIENT Centrifugal Pumping Machinery In the world, suitable fcr all purposes, including RECLAMATION, DRAINAGE, IRRIGATION, SEWAGE WORKS, GRAVING & FLOATING DOCKS, MINES, & ALL MANUFACTURING PURPOSES.
These Pumps can be driven by Steam, Gas, Oil, Water, Electricity, or other power, for Lifts of from 1 ft. to 500ft., and from 5 to 500,000 Gallons a Minute. Makers of the Mex Pumps.
Results Guaranteed.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED .
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
Subscribed Capital JS1.5oo,ooo
Paid up '' £ 5oo,ooo
Reserve Fund... 5oo,ooo
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Yesterday opened with a light breeze from the N.N.E. but towards noon the wind suddenly changed to the N.N.W. The day was rather warm, but becme beautifully cool in the evening. Barometer steady.

To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.

THURSDAY, JULY 13, 1905.

div.head: THE PROSPECTS OF PEACE.
div.p: We cannot say that the latest news from the United States gives any sore hope of peace. M. de Witte has reiterated, time oat of mind, that Russia will pay no war in- demnity, and even though the tribute levied oo the vanquiahed be styled "a reimbursement for war expenses"—an expression we oan cor- dially recommend to future conqueror*—we doubt whether all the gilding in the world will make Russia swallow the pilL The long delay since the victory of Mokdan has once more given the Russians time to reorganise their foroes and fill op their gaps, and though Qeneral Iinievitch does not bear the reputa- tion of a great strategist, and refugees from the scene of action tell stories of demora- lisation and incipient matiny among his soldiers, still, it must be remembered that similar tales have been spread abroad since Liao Yang, and that, in spite of them all, the Russian armies have never been routed, in the tense ol being not only defeated, bat demoralised for a considerable period after their defeat ; that, with the ooe exception of Port Arthur, avoidable surrenders on a large soale have been unknown; and that the Russian soldier, in spite of his iacompetent officers and imperfect training, always fights stub- bornly, and retreats with regret The viotory of Tsushima has saved Japan from all risk at defeat and has assured Liautong, Korea Md Bsfbalien to her soldiers, bat the Russian armies may fight a retreating battle, draw away to Lake Baikal or the Upper Amor valley, and, maintaining half a million man there, weary the Japeoese, who will be obliged to tutataio an approximately qual force in

Manchuria, into a oompromiao. In the ahock of battle the Japanese are perhaps invincible , but will even the heroes of the Shaho, Mukden, and Port Arthur prove themselves human after another two years of indecisive war t In the itixUsnth c-tntury one of the ablest of Asiatics, Toyotomi Hideyoahi, the Taiko-sama, or Great Lord, as the worshipper* at the shrine of his soul call him, led Japan to a five years' war of oinqueet in Korea against the Chinese and Koreans, which ended in the failure of all his plans, not so much through iU-euooess, as through the bitter home-sickness which is one of the prioea a patriotic army has to pay for a long campaign across the seas. Our soldier* un- doubtedly grew homaiiok and 'stale' in South Africa, and it will be atrange if even the mo*t ardent Japaneee soldier ha* not aome of the edge taken ofi hi* martial temper *fter more rainy aummen and icy winter.- in the Manchurian plains.

AU will depend, in our opinion, on the ability of Russia to play a long, slow, and unattractive game, without hope of any real victory—for the prisee of the.war must be to the Japaneee—but simply and solely with a view to making the peaoe terms leu onerous. And we submit that on this point the Russians themselves are the only possible judges. Were the revolutionary party in Russia led by oapable men, a long war might lead to the tall of the Tsardom, bat the earning cruise of the Potemkin, the failure of the striker* at Odessa to do more than provoke a nmnere, and the fact that a large section of the Russian people •teem* oontented with the promite* of relorm solemnly affirmed by the Tsar, makes us inclined to suspect that the Tsar'e govern- ment will take the risk* of revolution. Bat a long struggle in the Bast must still further weaken Russian infiuenoe and prestige in the West, and from this obvious decline of her infiuenoe and prestige, mast be born the inducements to make peaoe quickly with the Japaneee. The mast pro-Gercn«a Russian cannot but feel dismayed at tho growth of German influence in theNearEi*t,theadvooato of expansion in the Middle Bast must feel alarm at tho rapid extension of British in- fiuenoe in the Persian Gulf; and it must be a galling reflection that Russia oau have now no say in Scandinavian politics, and oannot offer France more than platonio support in Moroooo. Thirty years ago Russia might perhaps have abandoned western politios and striven for years to minimise defeat in theEtst,but events move rapidly now-a-days, and Russia's effaoe meat as a European power for a few years may prove a terrible handicap to her for another generation.

div.head: THE PEACE TERMS.
div.p: INDEMNITY REFUSED..
INTERNED WARSHIPS TO BE SURRENDERED.
PORTSMOUTH (N.H.), August 11.
M. Witte and Baron de Rosen have been closeted with the technical advisers for four hours during the afternoon.
The, reimbursement of war expenses, the amount of which is left to future determination, sad the cession of Saghalien, are the main eatures of the Japanese demands. The word identy is avoided.

Liter The other Japanese terms are the Session of Russia's lesse of the Liaotong leana, the etacuation of the whole of Mancris, the cession to Japan of the railroad S of Kharbin, the northern portion remsing Russian. The establishment of a Japanese protectorate in Keres, the limitation

Russia's naval strength in the Far East, the recession to China of any Russian privileges Ni Manchuria, an the granting of fishing hts on the Siberian littoral from Vladivos tok to Bebring Sea, to the Japanese Japan w requish her clain to the interned warships.
(Router).
PORTSMOUTH (N.H.), August 11.
the despatch relating to the Japanese pace conditions read: Russia relinquishes the interned warships to Japan.
There is a period of suspense here, pending. the arrival of the Russian reply to the Japanese nditions, which is expected to-morrow, or possibly to-night.
Later). It is learned that M. Witte accepts a. the Japanese conditions as bases of discuson, except the isdemnity and the cession of Sagialien. (Reuter.)
PORTSMOUTH (U.S.A.), August 11.
Witte will give his answer to-morrow morg, accepting the Japanese peace terms with the exception of the repayment of the War expenses and the cession of Saghalien.
(Havas.)
LONDON, August 11.

The Daily Telegraph" learns from Ports- Louth (N.H.) that on examining the Japanese. credentials it was found by the Russians that, while the Tear empowers them to make and accept conditions in his name, and undertakes to sanction anything that they sign, the Mikadio requires every stipulation to be submitted to him. In consequence of this, at yesterday morning's sitting the Russians, in order to equalise the respective powers, stated that they will not avail themselves of the authority to sign a treaty without reference to the Tsar. (Reuter.)
TOKIO, August 11.
211 Russion officers and men have surrendered in Saghalien since the 8th instant. (R.)

div.head: PARLIAMENT PROROGUED.
div.p: SPEECH FROM THE THRONE.
LONDON, Angust 11.

The Parliament has been prorogued. The Speech from the Throne dwells upon the friendly relations existing between Great Britain and other Powers. It expresses an earnest hope that the Russo-Japanese negotia tiens will lead to a lasting and mutually honorable peace.

The bases of the Morocco conference are under consideration. The dissolution of Sweden and Norway is apparently imminent, but confidence is expressed that such a settlement will be reached as will enable us to maintain the same friendly relations with Scandinavia as in the past.
Macedonia and Crete cause considerable anxiety and or gage the attention of the Powers. (Reuter
LONDON, August 11.
The speech from the Throne closing the session expresses the hope that peace will be copaluded.
(Hargs.)

div.head: THE FRENCH FETES.
div.p: LUNCH AT WINDSOR...
LONDON, August 11.

The French petty officers and men were entertained at luncheon by the Lord Mayor at The Guildhall. There was a repetition of yesterday's enthusiasm, Admiral Caillard and the officers lunched with the King at Windsor. (Reuter.)
LONDON, August 11.
The King has given a lucch at Windsor Castle to the officers of the French squadron. (Havas.)
LONDON, August 11..

The relief expedition has rescued and brought to Hammerfest the American Ziegler Polar Expedition, which sailed in June 1903. The ship was crushed and sunk in January 1904. The crew reached Franz Joseph land, after enduring terrible hardships, and subsisted on the stores left by previous expeditions.
MANCHESTER, August 11.
Three large cotton mills at Ashton have conceded an advance of 5% to their workmen.
(Reuter.)
Anglo-American Nile Steamer.
& HOTEL COMPANY. RIVER TRANSPORT OF 0000S BETWEEN ALEXANDRIA & DAIRO Three Sallings a-Wook. Agents at Alesandria:-
ALEXANDRIA 29NOFD WAREHOUSE 06. LA.

div.head: THE ERINDISI MAIL
div.p: will be dispatched from Alexandria General Post Office, at 3.15 p.m. on Monday. Registered letters must be posted by 2.15 p.m., and insured articles and money. orders, by noon.

div.head: TRAM ACCIDENT.
div.p: A tram car ran over a native named Mahnioud Salem Abou Shoula at Sidi Gaber yesterday, inflicting injuries. that will require twenty five-days' treatment in hospital.

div.head: SUEZ CANAL.
div.p: 12 vessels passed throngh the Canal on the 9th inst., of which 9 were British, 3 German, 1 French. The day's receipts were frs. 322,204 45, making the total from the 1st inst. fra. 2,322,204 45.

div.head: THE ROTATIONS-
div.p: The Ministry of Public Works has decided to suppress the rotations, for lands on the Ismailia Canal as well as the canals in the Mudirieh of Galonbieb,' commencing from to morrow, August 18.

div.head: ALHAMBRA THEATRE
div.p: A matinée will be given by the Dalla Guardia Dramatic Company when La Stratagemma di Serafino will be represented, commencing at 4 p.m. In the evening La Figlia di Torio will be played.

div.head: NARROW ESCAPE.-
div.p: A little native girl named Aziza bint Mohamed fell into the sea near the Custom House yesterday but, was fortunately rescued in time and sent to the hos spital, where the necessary medical aid was forthcoming.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA CRICKET CLUB
div.p: The cricket match, which was to have been played this afternoon between the A.C.C. XI. and next XVI, has been cancelled on account of the sad bathing fatality by which Captains Stokes and Carey lost their lives.

div.head: COAL IMPORTS.
div.p: From the 1st/of January to the 10th August, 569,868 tons of coal were imported into Egypt. Wales sont 311,454, Newcastle 127,974, Scotland 74,028, Yorkshire 33,934 and other places 22,478 tons. During the same period in 1904, 601,113 tons were received.

div.head: THE LATIN PATRIARCHATE-
div.p: Reports from Jerusalem state that Mgr. Aurelio Briante will probably succeed Mgr. Piavi as Latin Patriarch of Jerusalem, and be succeeded at Alexandria by Mgr. Giannini, who is now at Beyrout. We have been unable to obtain confirmation of these reports.

div.head: THE MAHMAL THEFT.-
div.p: The superior Council of War will assemble on Wednesday next for the trial of Miralaï Mohamed Rafaat, who was the officer in charge of the military escort that accompanied the Mahmal when the Sorra, was stolen at Abbassieh, and who is accused of grave negligence. The case against Andraous Meloka and his accomplices, who are charged with the theft of the money, will come on very shortly before the Assize Court in Cairo.

div.head: THE PLAGUE.-
div.p: Yesterday's plague bulletin. reports three admissions to hospital and one death at Alexandria, one recovery at Ashmoun and another one at Dekerness, The death at Alexandria was that of a Copt boy, who was suffering from pneumonia. The three new cases admitted are those of a native workman belonging to a disinfection gang, another workman, also a native, inhabiting the Kour Bakir district, and a young native girl from the Kom el-Shugafeh district.

div.head: AN ECHO OF THE JOURNEY OF ALPHONSE XIIT -
div.p: It is known that one of the principal attractions of Paris at the time of the visit of King Alphonse XIII. was the decoration of the Berlitz School, 27 Avenue de l'Opera, which was afterwards reproduced in the principal illustrated papers. But what is not generally known is that His Majesty, after having admired the fine decoration in question on his way, sent a telephone message from the Elysée to the Direction of the Berlitz School to declare his satisfaction. Alphonse XIII, studied by the Berlitz system both German and English, and has perfected his knowledge of French, thanks to that system. His Majesty recently received in private audience at Madrid Mr. Berlitz, who was travelling in Spain, and expressed his gratitude and admiration of the system. [ADVT.].

div.head: OBITUARY.
div.p: REV. BROCHER SYLVANUS.
The many friends of the Christian Brothers will learn with deep regret of the death of the Rev. Brother Sylvanus, which took place at Marseilles on the 20th of last month.

This distinguished and sympathetic teacher spent the greater part of his life in the Bast St. Catherine's College had the happiness of possessing him among its numerous staff for many a year. His sole desire during his long and laborions career, was to give to the obildren committed to his paternal care a good moral and intellectual training. A solemn Requiem Mass for the repose of his soul will be sung at the Brothers' chapel on Monday, the 14th inst. at 7.30 a.m.
Mme Vve de Koningh and the families de Koningh and Antonio Cilia deeply regret to announce the death at Marseilles, yesterday, of Mr. Jan de Koningh,

div.head: BRITISH OFFICERS DROWNED.
div.p: SAD BATHING/ACCIDENT.

We deeply regret to announce the death from drowning of Capt. C. H. G. Stokes and Capt. E. S. Carey of the 2nd Royal Inniskilling Fasiliers. The two officers arrived at the Hotel Beau Rivage at about 1 p.m. yesterday, and after lunch went down to bathe from the beach. There are apparently no boats at this part of the shore, and no regular bathing place, the public bathing at their own risk.

As far as can be gathered, Capt, Stokes, while swimming about 120 yards ont, was seized with an attack of syncope. Capt. Carey, who was a strong swimmer, at once came. to his rescue, but, in attempting to aid him, was himself caught by the current and carried ont. He called for help, but to the shame of the crowd of about a hundred persons, mostly natives, who stood on the shore, no one stirred, with the exception of Capt Crawley, A.S.C., who, though. suffering from the effects of a wound received in South Africa, made two gallant but unsuccessfal efforts to rescue the drowning officers at considerable personal risk. About ten minutes after Capt. Carey bad last been seen his body came to the surface nearer the shore, and was brought in. Attempts were imme liately made to restore consciousness and Drs. Kanzky and Ambinini, who arrived some twenty minutes later, did all that was in their power, but their efforts were unavailing. The body of Captain Stokes was discovered near the beach an hour later.

An inquest was held this morning at Ras-el Tin hospital which had not terminated at the time of our going to press. A representative detachment of the officers and men of the 2nd Inniskilling Fasiliers stationed at Cairo arrives at Alexandria by special train at 4 p.m. to-day, to pay the last honours to the deceased officers, who had done good service in South Africa and were deservedly popular with all who knew them. General Bullock has arrived from Cairo for the same purpose, and the 2nd Royal Berkshire Regt. will join the Irish Regiment in paying the last honours to the dead at the military faneral, which leaves the Bourse at about 5p.m. We should like to express our deep sympathy and that of our readers with the relatives and comrades of the deceased officers, on the sad loss that they have sustained.

div.head: COUNCIL OF MINISTERS.
div.p: The Council of Ministers, which met on Thursday last at Ramleb, has ordered the dismissal from the public service of Hassan Wassit Bey, ex-Moudir of Ghirgeh, who is deprived of all rights to pension or indemnity. The other decisions of the Minister refer chiefly to expropriations of land for purposes of public utility, and to sales by the Domains Administration. We also notice that the Railways Administration is to be sole judge in future as to the practicability of adding res taurant cars to trains in answer to the demands of the public.

div.head: CREMATION IN EGYPT.
div.p: The Sanitary Department has just published an "arrêté" concerning cremation, by which is prescribed that the ovens must be constructed According to the plans drawn up by the Administration, and must receive their authori- sation. The incineration of the bodies of Moslems is forbidden,and in other cases a body may not be cremated except upon the presen tation of proof of the verbal or written wishes of the deceased. Any infringement of these regulations will be punishable by a fine of P.T. 100, and by not more than one week's imprisonment.

div.head: CAIRO ASSIZES.
div.p: The present session of the Cairo Assize Court opened to-day at the buildings of the Native Court of Appeal. The trial of Leon Fehmi, who is accused of having attempted to obtain money from Mohamed Pasha Orphi by threats, takes place on Monday. Yehia Bey Ibrahim will act as presiding judge, Maitre Ragheb Abd el Fahim has been retained for the defence, while Maitre Mohamed Bay Sadik is counsel for Orphi Pasha.

On the same day will be heard the case of Andraous Meloks and his accomplices, charged with the theft of part of the treasure which accompanied the Mahmal. Me. Fawaris Bey Mikhail will appear, for the defence in a Case which should be of great public interest. UNDESIRABLES EXPELLED.

The cigarette maker G. Theophilopoulo of Cairo, who recently threatened M. Georgaco- Don'o, with death, failing the production of a large sum of money, has been expelled from Egypt by the Hellenic Consular authorities.. An American subject, who recently threatened Mr. Broadbent, the American Conenl at Port Said, has also been packed off to New York and the Governorat of Alexandria has followed suit, deporting four undesirables, who have already been expelled only to re appear like the proverbial bad penny.

div.head: SAN STEFANO CASINO.
div.p: The following is the vocal part of the programme to be performed at the San Stefano Casino concert to-morrow, commencing at 10.30 a.m. This part will commence at 11 a.m. Ballo in Maschera, Verdi, Romance pour Soprano, Mile Cantoni a) Tosti, Ideale, Melodis b) Giordano, Fodora, Amor ti vieto Mr. Giovanelli Romance de l'Etoile pour baryton, Tannhanser, Wagner, Mr. Greggio Mile Canton! Mr. Giovanelli Groggio.
Trovatore, Verdi, Terzetto lo atto

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner "Rameses" arrived yesterday afternoon from Liverpool, via Malta, with passengers, mails and general cargo,

div.head: THE ZOO'S NEW ADDITIONS.
div.p: A SPLENDID COLLECTION.

We mentioned in our issue of Thursday that Captain Plower, Director of the Zoological Gardens at Ghizeh, had arrived early that morning in Cairo on his return from an expedi tion to the Sudan with a large and varied collection of wild animals, reptiles, and birds to add to the already magnificent collection to be found in the gardens. Several of the new additions are rare specimens, a few not having been seen in this country before, and the whole lot just arrived are well worth a visit.

The total number of mammals in the new collection are fifty, the most important being fifteen cub lions captured in all parts of the Sudan by natives, and presented by different Anglo-Egyptian officiale This lot is intended for the Government of India, who have asked for them to be sent out and in return promised to present the Egyptian Government with a collection of Indian animals for the Cairo Zoc. These lions will be forwarded shortly to nez for shipment to Bombay and Calcutta, some being for the Calcutta Zoo, and the rest to be given as presents to reigning Rajahs. The ages of the animals vary from three to ten months, the younger ones being very docile, and playful as kittens.

Amongst the collection is a very handsome female giraffe from Kordofan, just over eleven feet high, which will soon be rent away to Constantinople, as a gift to the Sultan from the Khedive, at whose special request it was brought down from Khartoum,

With the exception of the above two lots, the rest of the recent arrivals are intended for the local Zoo. The first as regards importance, and which are the most interesting, are three baby elephants, captured by Arabs in the opper waters of the Blue Nile, and are aa playful as the cab lion's mentioned above. One of theee was presented by Captain McMurdo, D.S.O., Director of the Slave Trade Department, and the other two were purchased. These elephants: are from eight to ten months old, and are very rarely found in captivity, those now in Cairo being most probably the first ever brought there, only about half a dozen others being known to exist in the different zoological gardens of the world. These alone are well worth seeing.

Another interesting new specimen is a Ratel (Mellivora Ratel), brought from Renk on the White Nile, and presented by Mr. L. Gorringe of the Slave Trade Department. This animal belongs to the badger family, and is the first of its kind exhibited at the Ghiseh gardens,. The reptiles in the collection number fourteen. These include six crocodiles, all from the Blue Nile; three are only a few months old and the largest is about seven and a half feet long. The other reptiles are two river turtles from the Blue Nile; three terrapins or water tortoises (Sternotharus Adansoni) from the White Nile, presented by Bimbashi Scott-Hill, R.N.; two leopard tortoises (Testudo Pardalis) from Bor, on the White Nile. One of these latter was presented by Bimbashi the Hon. M. P. Macnaghten, and the other by Captain B. L. Mears, of the A.S.C. at Khartoum.

The new collection of birds brought by. Captain Flower numbers sixty-four in all, belonging to twenty different species. The more important among these include a fish eagle from the White Nile, the first of its kind exhibited, and which was presented by Mr. G. B. Middleton; two Senegal or saddle-billed storke from the Sobat River in the south of the Sadan, which are very rare birds to be found in collections. They were presented by Dr. H. T. MacLaughlan, of the American Mission. Last, but not least, amongst the fine lot of the feathered tribe is a glossy starling from the White Nile. This is a very pretty bird,and the first of its species seen at Ghizsh. It was given by Mr. A. L. Butler, head of the Game Preservation Department at Khartoum,

Captain Flower, was away for just three months, having left Cairo on the 11th May, and having travelled during that time 3,600) miles by river and road, going as far as Rosaires on the Blue Nile, where a great deal of rain was encountered. It took from five to six weeks to reach Cairo on the return journey, Rosaires having been left on the 2nd July. The constant rains were the cause of almost all the Egyptian keepers being laid up with malarial fever, which lasted during most of the return journey. The animals, reptiles, and birds were brought from different focalities, and collected at Khartoum, whence the entire collection was conveyed to Waly Halfa by goods train, and from the latter place down the river to Cairo by sailing boats which were towed part of the way by Government steamer, and the rest by one of Cook's express steamers. Great difficulty was encountered on the journey down in finding sufficient quantities of meat and milk for the animals bat, fortunately, no hitch occurred,and the entire number arrived at their destination in excellent condition. Captain Flower was in capital health daring the whole trip, despite the intense heat at most times, and was unaccompanied by any other Baropean. The expedition, besides. himself, consisted of eleven Egyptians, one Bedouin, and one negro, all of whom returned safely, notwithstanding the attacks of malarial fever.

Besides the collection of animals for the Zoo, another was made of some sixty specimens of many species of Nile fish, at the request of the British Museum, These were preserved in spirits, and will be utilised for the forth- coming report to be published by the Egyptian Government in conjunction with the Museum authorities in London. This report will be mainly founded on the splendid collection made for the Government by Mr. W. L. 8. Loat a few years ago, during three seasons.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Lady Blomfjeld is giving an "At Home" on Friday the 18th inat. on board H.H.S. Aida, when her guests will be taken to see the Ad miralty dredgers, which have arrived lately, at work in the New Pass

Paris papers bring news of the marriage of M. Henri Lamba, the well-known Cairo advocate, and professor at the Khedivial Law School, and Mme Madeleine Sturel, which took place at Paris on the 28th inst. Our hearty congratulations.
The Rev. Père Cotet, rector of the College. of the Holy Family, left Port Said for Beyrout yesterday Père Cotet intends to take six week's holiday in the Lebanon..

div.head: PASSENGER LISTS.
div.p: ARRIVALS.

The followed passengers arrived yesterday per Moss liner 8.8. Menes:-Mr. P. Newbury, Mr. O. A. Tilley, Mr. W. E. Peel, Miss Bessic Haynes, Master T. Field, Mrs. Alice Rausey, Mrs. J. Romeo; Rev. Father Agins, Mr. Carita and 21 deck passengers.
Per P. & O. 8.8. Sumatra, from London to Port Said-Miss Florence Lloyd and Mr. and Mrs. Richmond.
DEPARTURES.

Le paquebot "Sénégal" dea Messageries Ma ritimes parti hier pour Marseille avait à bord: M. Agathon Bay, Mme Thonneyer, Dr. J. G. Ebed, R. Père Fournier, M. C. Tsivily, M. A. Bereketti, M. Habib Nosson, M. Mansour Be- yabed, M. A. Asadian, R. Remi Leprêtre, M. 1. Salhami, Mme Haller, M. A. Simon, Mrs Alex. et René Collonge, M. et Mme Chande ron, M. et Mme Khouloussy, Mile Pigretelli, Mme Guerlot M. Brouard, M. R. Campana, M. et Mme A. Khalil Bey, M. Flick, M. Yebia Bey, Famille Camsaracan, M. A. Haddad, General Camsaracan, M. A. Ismalun, M. W. Denning, M. Bowen, Mme Cabane, Mme Latour, Mlle Miedan, M. I. Aslan, Mme A. Degiorgio, Frères Camille, Isidore et Jean, Mile Marie, Pères Le Bayon, Rosensweig, Père Pinaie, Famille Autofage, M. Taylor, Mlle P. Kefani, M. A.. S. Kadre, 5 officiers da "St. Giles," M. S. B. Pall, M. L. Salomon et 67 passagers de 39 et 4me classes.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY.
div.p: CRICKET.
EGYPT v. LONDON COUNTY
(BY SPECIAL WIRE).
London, August 11.

The cricket match which was played on the Crystal Palace Grounds between Egypt and the London County XI. on the 9th and 10th inst. ended in a fairly even draw. London County, who had the first choice of innings, made 293 runs at their first attempt, and Egypt replied with 161 runs. On going in a second time London County made 154 for five wickets, when they declared, and Egypt batted with much better result than in the first innings, scoring 116 runs for the loss of only two wickets, at which point stumps were drawn, and the match left undecided. Details will follow by the first mail.

div.head: LETTER TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit within certain necessary limits-free lecqandon.

div.head: COTTON MANUFACTURERS' LOSSES.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.

Sir, I bave read the interesting article in your issue of Saturday, headed "Lord Cromer- His Life and Work" by Mr. Harold Spender. Int it the writer writes as follows: "The next step was to reduce taxation and that process is still anfinished. But the severest burdens have been relaxed. The tax on sheep and goats, the tax on all trades and crafts, the tax on fishing, all these, and many other smaller but still oppressive burdens, have been remitted." I beg to point out to you, Mr. Editor, that this is not correct, for it is well known that both the Egyptian Cotton Mills, Cairo, and the Alexandria Spinning and Weaving Company,. Ltd, have to pay at the present time excise duty to the extent of 8% (lesa 20%) on the values of all goods manufactured by them. These are the only manufacturers taxed in Egypt, please note. It has been said that this duty has been imposed to protect Lancashire. How on earth on this imposition protect Lancashire manufacturers The only way of protecting them is by closing the mills altogether so that they cannot manufacture the like goods.

If the mills here can work at all, there is no protection by imposing a duty of this sort, and it only resolves itself into a tax on Egyptian labor, as all the workpeople are Arabs,and this imposition comes out or the pockets of the shareholders, who are, excepting a very few, residents of Egypt.-I am, Sir, etc.,

div.head: BECK & CO'S PILSENER BEER
div.p: Obtalasble, from every IN CAIRO, ARSHANDES

div.head: CHRONIQUE FINANCIERE
div.p: Le marché n'a pas présenté cette semaine la même animation que la semaine passée. La saison d'été bat son plein et ici comme ent Barope les gros financiers sont en villégiature. Un'congé de deux jours est encore vanu interrompre les transactions à Londres d'où l'on sait que notre place dépend principalement. Toutes ces considérations prises ensemble font. qu'il y a platot liet de s'étonner du mouve ment qui s'est produit, malgré tout, sur certaines de nos valeurs.

Un fait digne de remarque c'est que l'argent a renchéri en Europe où le taux d'escompte haussé de 1 3/4 2 1/4. Quant au naméraire local, il est difficile de rien préciserà son égard, va le grand nombre de banques nouvelles qui se sont récemment établies ici. Le Comptoir National d'Escompte dont on connait Pétat Horissant aiders beaucoup au développement des affaires. Grâce aux facilités qu'il offre, plusieurs clients mécontents de trop étroites exigeances de leur banque ont.déjà passé chez lui avec armes et bagages. Le Banco di Roma a également contribué depuis 3 mois à faciliter, les échanges par l'empressement qu'il met à avancer sur les titres de premier ordre avec une marge raisonnable. Nous aurons aussi prochainement la Banque de Salonique qui dé- pend, comme on le sait, de la K. & K. Oeste reische Landerbank, Nous espérons qu'avec ces nouvelles banques,, notre marché recevra l'appoint qui lui manquait.

On ne sait encore rien de précis à propos de ia Banque d'Abyssinie. Aussin'a-t-on pas traité d'affaires cette semaine. La version la plus" accréditée serait que les actions de cette nonvelle Banque seront lancées sur le marché an moyen d'une émission publique...

L'Agricole débute à 14 1/8 pour cloturer à 14 1/32. On s'attend à une reprise à la rentrée des capitalistes d'Europe. La Nouvelle fléchit de 9 9/16 à 9 7/16 acheteurs. L'ex right est de 1,8 au-dessus parce qu'elle a droit au coupon de l'année courante. De 1,035 la Part de Fondatear monte à £1,045 si la vague ru mear d'après laquelle on diviserait ces Parts en centièmes se réalisait, le cours de cette valeur hausserait sensiblement, selon toute: apparence.
La National Bank fléchit de 27 7/16 à 27 5/16 pour remonter en clôture à 27 3/8, La Nou velle suit les mêmes fluctuations, avec 1/32 de différence en moins.
De 9 3/8 la Land Bank monte à 9 1/2, prix auquel elle clôture.

L'Action Crédit Foncier flactae 'entre-818 et 822 pour finir à 820 acheteurs. Li hausse des Parts de Fondateur s'accentue rapidement de 9,350 à 9,900; on s'attend à des cours encore plus élevés après la combinaison avec la Daira qui fera spécialement bénéficier les Parts de Fondateur.

En raison de la distribution d'an dividende intérimaire de P.T. 20 et de rumeurs favorables concernant l'établissement d'une succursale à Londres et une émission nouvelle en décembre, la Cassa di Sconto monte de 186 à 195. Elle clôture & 193.
La Banque d'Athènes demeure stationnaire entre 127.1/4 et 127 3/4. Le dernier bilan été bien accueilli.
Da 18 1/8 La Delta Light tombe à -13 1/32, mais ne tarde pas à se relever à 13 1/8. La Ramleh Railway reate calme entre 7 5/16 et 7 3/8, aveo affais limitées.

Une des valeurs les plus en vogue cette se maine a été l'Urbaine. De 5 1/4 le cours a haussé jusqu'à 5 1/2 pour olôturer à 5.7/16. De 28 5/16 la Daira Sanieh tombe gradualle ment jusqu'à 28, mais reprend légèrement en clotare 28 1/16. L'incertitude où l'on est encore au sujet des détails de la liquidation pousse nombre de spéculateurs à se retirer, mais les capitalistes n'en sont pas ébranlés et conti-. nuent à garnir leurs portefeuilles.
La Deterred Daïra tombe également de 181 179.
Il est question, paraft-il, d'an prochain dívdende en Delta Land, dont le prix est très Boutenu entre 2 23/32 et 2 3/4.
Les Privilégiées Tramways d'Alexandrie sont calmes entre 159 et 160 et les Dividendee entre 340 et 342.
Des ordres d'achats provenant de la Capitale on fait monter le cours des Eaux du Caire de 11301155.

Ce sont encore d'importants ordres d'achat. de la Capitale qui ont occasionné une forte poussée des Upper Egypt Hotels. De 4 15/16 le prix est monté hier à 5 15/32 pour finir à 5 8/8. Comme, en effet, la saison des touristes. promet d'être brillante, les Hotels seront les premiers à profiter de l'aubaine.
La Nungovich est très ferme à 10 8/16. Les Egyptian Hotels (Baebler) haussent de 2.7/16 29/16 et les Splendid Hotels de 4 3/16. 4 5/16.

Came d'abord à 22/9, les Markets sont ramontés soudain à 34, cours auquel ils oldtarent en forte demande. Comme, en dépit de la fermeture des marchés à bestiaux à cause de In reste bovine, les recettes ne laissent pas d'être satisfaisantes, les acheteurs augurent de ce fait une ère de prospérité dès que le fléati Ayant disparu les marchés fonctionneront de nouveau.
De 35/6 la Salt and Soda monte à 36/3 mais retombe bientôt à (35/7).

Des milliers de Khedivial Mail ordinary ont éé échangés dans le conrant de cette remaine entre 20 et 24. On c'ôtore à 23. On parle d'an dividende probable de 6 0/0. La Préfé- rence hausse do 1/2 à 49/16:

L'Investment moute de 1 5/16 à 13/8" et c'oture à 1 11/32 avec affaires restreintes. De 4 1/2 le Comptoir réactionne à 4 5/16 à l'arrivée des certificats provisoires au porteur. La c'ôture a lien à 4 3/8 en bonne tendance. L'Ang'o American Nile est calme entre 5 9/16 et 5 5/8.
D'importantes transactions ont été effectuésa an Batates entre 31/32 et 15/16. L'affaire de terrain que cette sociétés dernièrement conglue au Caire passe pour excellente.

On a fait plusieurs centaines d'Oasis entre 1 1.8 et 1 5/32. Le Nile Cold Storage hausen/ de 9 16 à 11/16. De 5 1/8 la Société Frigorifi que tombe à 5 pour se relever en alôture & 5 3/32. La Privilégiée Crown Brewery est ferme à 220, tandis que la Dividende s'avance le 120 125. La Privilégiée Brasserie des Pyramides est calme entre 181 et 123, pendant que la Dividende hausse de 60 à 63 après avoir touché 65.

D'une façon générale on peut dire dès à pré- sent que la Bourse a déjà escompté en partie l'insuccès des négociations de paix ruse japonaises, mais il va sans dire que le doute d'un écheo transformé en certitude affecterait défavorablement les marobés de tous les pays. Bi au contraire tout s'arrange, l'avenir se pré ente sous les plus riants présages,

div.head: ALEXANDRIA GENERAL PRODUCE ASSOCIATION
BULLETIN HEBDOMADAIRE
div.p: Alexandrie, VENDREDI à Midi le 14 Juillet 1905

row.cell: Pour les Feves, Orges, Bles, Lentilles, Mais et Oignons, la consommation locale n'est connue respectivement que les 31 Mars et 24 Novembre
N.B.– L'année pour les Blés et les Lentilles commence au 1er Avril, pour les Mais le 1er Décembre, pour les Oignons le 1er Mars.
COTON SUIVANT LES TYPES DE L'ASSOCIATION
Marché des Cotons: ferme, bonne demande.
